history.content: switch 126 with 127, beyond that you're fine if you can handle your current workload

children.subject: 61B/70/16B is also said to be a death wish, to be fair.

61B/70/16B+breadth is also a large workload, but 61C/170/126 + R&C seems worse. At least in my experience 61B < 61C workload, 70 < 170, and I haven't taken 126 but from what I hear it's also probably tougher than 16B. Also breadth courses can be easy or hard depending on the course, but R&C courses are pretty consistently a decent workload.
Yeah, and it seems like 16b wasn't as bad this semester because Professor Arcak and Sanders decreased the load quite a bit.

You could also do 

Fall 20

126

170

7B

Light breadth

Spring 21

127

189

R&C

And take 61C in the summer or a future semester

I considered that, but that would likely mean putting off some of the other upper divs I'm keen on until I finish 61C. (Probably won't have time to do it during summer alongside whatever else I'm doing.)

Since it is Schewchuk, I may content myself with just not doing 126 beforehand (and taking 127 concurrently), since I've heard 127 is more useful if I haven't taken Math 110. 

Anyways, both 126 and 127 are filled up for fall and I'm not sure if they'll expand during phase II or later so I probably won't be able to get in anyways.
Are you sure? From what I've heard, 61C/170/126 would be a death wish...

history.content:
Would like some advice on my intended course plan for the next two semesters:

Fall 20

CS 61C

CS 170

EE 127

[R&C B]

Spring 21

CS 189

EE 126

PHYS 7B

[light breadth]

For reference, I'm taking 61B (Hilfinger), 70 (Sahai/Ayazifar), 16B (Arcak/Sanders), and a breadth right now and find the workload perfectly fine. 70 problem sets can be challenging, but as a whole all three courses together don't feel too difficult. I could probably have added a little more on my plate.

I admit, I'm in a bit of a rush to get to 189 hence the addition of 127 into the Fall semester. Nevertheless, would still appreciate everyone's thoughts. 

Thanks!
history.subject: Thoughts on my course plan for next two semesters
